intro: Lupinus barkeri, commonly known as Barker's lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its tall, erect growth habit and clusters of violet to blue flowers. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open grasslands and disturbed sites. Lupinus barkeri is also valued for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil, benefiting other plants in its ecosystem.
